author: Graeme Whitfield
title: 31,000 small companies in North East would be hit by Brexit, campaigners say
text:
31,000 small companies in North East would be hit by Brexit, campaigners say 15:59, 31 May 2016 15:59, 31 May 2016 By Graeme Whitfield Britain Stronger in Europe say 31,000 SMEs in the North East either trade in Europe or supply firms that do Shares Get business news by email Business Secretary Sajid Javid 
Tens of thousands of small businesses in the North East would be hit if the UK votes to leave the European Union, Business Secretary Sajid Javid has warned. 
The Cabinet minister said it was a “dangerous” misconception to believe that smaller firms would be unaffected by Brexit after the Britain Stronger in Europe said that 31,000 firms in the North East either export to Europe or supply firms that do export. 
Opinion on the EU in the small business community is much more mixed than among larger companies, with polls by bodies such as the Federation of Small Businesses showing support for EU membership but at much lower levels. 
But Mr Javid said small firms were the “backbone of our economy” and the livelihoods of millions of workers could be put at risk if the country breaks from Brussels on June 23. 
Citing the number of companies in the region that rely on trade with Europe, Mr Javid said: “This shows yet again that small businesses across the North East are stronger, safer and better off in Europe. 
“If we leave the EU, small firms are on the front line and that’s a gamble with people’s livelihoods I’m not willing to take. Small businesses are the backbone of our economy. Let’s not break that backbone with a leap into the dark.” 
Britain Stronger in Europe also highlighted comments from a number of North East firms backing the Remain Campaign. 
Charlie Gibbs, director of Gateshead-based company Steampunk Gin, said: “We are a small but growing gin business who are looking to expand by exporting into countries all across Europe. At the moment, once we have established new customers, doing business is easy. 
“We don’t have to worry about import tariffs, local VAT or duty variations because all these deals have been done en-bloc through the European construct we currently have. 
“If this was to be denied to us, who knows what kind of deals our Government would be able to do with a multiplicity of countries? There is no guarantee that we could be in the same bargaining position as we are today. 
“In addition, we source round 80% of our raw materials from EU countries, which means we pay no local VAT due to the reciprocal arrangements we have now. If, for example, we had to start paying Germany 19% VAT that we could not claim back, then that 19% increase would need to be passed onto our customers, who in turn would be passing it onto consumers.” 
But John Longworth, former director-general of the British Chambers of Commerce who now chairs the Vote Leave Business Council, said: “These Government figures are extremely questionable. 
“The reality is that only 6% of British firms export to the EU, but 100% are caught up in red tape and costs from Brussels. If we Vote Leave and take back control of our economy, our businesses will thrive.”
